In addition to looking at what type of early intervention programs the local school district might have, there may also be programs at a local college of university through their child development program.  And, if your husband is affiliated with a hospital, particularly if it is a good teaching hospital he may be able to get a line on some programs. Frankly, based on your description of your son, finding "day care" might need to take a back seat to finding him the help he needs to be successful down the road.  Good Luck!

Superb work Dan!

Unbridled competition between producers -- the Econ 101 fantasy of many buyers, many sellers, no one of which has control over price -- is a Malthusian nightmare for the producers. That world existed in the 1880s. The titans of industry reorganized into corporations in the 1890s so that it would never happen again -- and it hasn't. Corporations control their markets, their owners claiming an outsize share of national income. James Livingston has details:
https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/602561885

Yeah, that's the answer and it's a miracle the tycoons at Wal-Mart haven't thought of it yet: Get some intra-company competition going between lawn and garden and hardware and only lower wages for the losers. Note that nobody would ever expect Wal-Mart to try using positive incentives on their employees.

Even if they ever could see that competition within a company wouldn't necessarily be good for morale or gross sales, let's be serious about expecting them to ever see that anything other than unbridled competition between companies might ever be good for the economy. Whether it's big vs. small, old tech vs. high tech, Exxon vs. clean energy, or Microsoft vs. the Justice Department, the venerable Invisible Free Hand is all we'll ever need.

Actually, it's all they'll ever need to keep on ripping off consumers and employees, to keep avoiding taxes, and to keep paying themselves salaries and other benefits far beyond anything they actually deserve.

Obviously you are correct in your assumptions regarding secrecy but secrecy is not privacy and it is not related to privacy when one considers Snowden.

Secrecy covers a broad area, Privacy covers and individual area. A person may have a large area of land that they consider private but that does not make it secret. If you trespass upon that private land you are not assuming a secret, hence the word trespass. As a person I may consider that the amount of my disposable income is my secret, but it is not private as my banker and department stores already have a very good idea of what it is.

The difference comes down to the same as gender and sex. Think of gender right along side of secrecy and think of sex right along side of privacy. When any entity or person has a secret it is a precaution against making public what is usually within public domain. An entity can not have privacy, a person can.

I'm getting bored having to type and retype this message. But here goes:
1. Privacy is a social convention and at times a legal obligation. It exists to the extent that social pressure and legal consequences attendant upon it are accepted and can be enforced.
2. Secrecy is a physical condition, and it no longer exists in our modern world. It existed to some degree by virtue of physical separation, when we were an agrarian society. During that time, we developed a mode of privacy based on secrecy. But, again, there is no more secrecy.
3. There are at least two reasons why there is no more secrecy.
a. Digital technology makes everything available to everyone, images included. This can be delayed and thwarted to some degree, but in the end, anyone can acquire any data with a modicum of skill and motivation.
b. Data are valuable. There is simply too much money/power/control/ whatever in possessing data to be denied. It is the cocaine of the flat world.
4. What can be done?
a. Accept reality, and stop wasting time pining for secrecy - it's impossible.
b. Make data less valuable or interesting where possible. Individual medical data loses value with community rating - when everybody pays the same for insurance no matter what, individual data have no value. Make your data uninteresting.
c. See 3.a above. Spy back! Snowden has shown how little protection the big guys really have. Our national security will require our government to recognize and adapt to this fact.

What you do in a public place is viewable without a warrant.  Always was.

To maintain privacy: If there are to be surveillance cameras, the video should not be viewable or processable without an individual warrant specifying exactly what was sought, excluding all other discoveries and their fruit.
It WAS gender discrimination cuz if she were male she would NOT have aroused jealousy in the wife who prompted her husband to fire a beautiful female.
It is still discrimination based on appearance. Maybe it is not codified into law, but the unfairness of the verdict is clear.

Thank you for this.  I think given the circumstances it's perfectly reasonable to believe that this firing was based on personal relationships and is not really a comment on overarching societal themes of gender and injustice.  I'm very aware those themes exist and must be addressed, but I try and be critical in considering cases like this instead of applying a filter that says it MUST be sexism when a woman is fired on sketchy grounds.

I'd encourage Times readers to look up the Iowa Supreme Court opinion. The Iowa Supreme Court agrees that Dr. Knight's firing of Ms. Nelson amounted to poor treatment, but finds that the firing was based on their personal relationship and the fears and wishes of Dr. Knight's wife, rather than on gender grounds. The decision is bolstered by precedent, as well as by the fact that Knight exclusively hires female dental assistants and replaced Knight with a woman. The court also noted that although Nelson had done nothing improper, she and Knight had a personal friendship that concerned Knight's wife.

In this case, the court was able to link the firing to the specific relationship between Knight and Nelson, rather than gender discrimination. It's a subtle distinction which some reject, but the court does have a theory of law and relevant precedent on which to rely.

Cute. "Financial Engineering."  Most people call that Cooking The Books, and it's also the reason most PE leveraged buyouts are able to "create value."  Too bad that value is almost exclusively market value, not anything long-term, like a customer base, market position, human capital, or any other asset that can generate returns for decades, not merely months.

The organization of the firm is actually an interesting case study for efficient market theory. If we're to accept the EMH, the market would lead fairly rapidly toward an optimal organization of firms across the economy. But if you look at the actual history of firm organization over the last 60 years or so, it's been very haphazard.

You had a big wave of conglomeration mergers of the 60's. When those proved inefficient, you had breakups of those same conglomerates in the 70's. Then you had the rise of LBOs and the big wave of buyouts in the 80's. Recently, there's a whole lot of companies being flipped between private equity firms. More often than not, the portfolio company eventually ends up in bankruptcy, often more than once by the end of the process.

That's not to say the buyout funds never create value; there is pretty good data showing that private equity firms do end up creating value over the medium run, especially in the early years of a PE boom. There's also a good deal of financial engineering that ends in a lot of sound and fury and no payoff (like, famously, RJR Nabisco), or active redistribution of resources away from labor and toward management and investors (Shleifer/Summers 88 identified that phenomenon first, I think).

But the organizational problems not just at Sears but also, famously, at Microsoft (Vanity Fair ran an interesting article about it last year) shows that the market is pretty bad at identifying efficient organizational structures.

This article has a few inaccuracies.  Firstly, the Nooks that Pogue is referring to are the Nook HD (the 7") and the Nook HD+ (the 9"), not the Nook Color, which was an earlier model that is no longer available.  Secondly, Barnes and Noble has stated that they will continue producing the Nook Simple Touch and the Nook Simple Touch with Glowlight, so the Nook library is going nowhere for the conceivable future.  People will still be able to read the books they have purchased from BN on any device they currently own as well as on the web (in addition to any apps for iOS or android).  Lastly, Amazon controls approximately 60% of the ebook market, with BN and Apple splitting the difference.  Until I hear rumblings that Apple is out of the game, I won't believe that BN is, either.
It's possible.  And possibly not.  How much do you know about the situation?

well, so what? If in certain cultures, there is a focus on complexity of duration, visual complexity, etc is emphasized, what is wrong with that?

Anthropology can show that there is no universal set of what is complex for music, or that are multiple clusters of complexity that music lovers tend to focus on. There would still be objective facts about music, but that differed based on cultural context to culture. Anthropology can't refute the subjective (in the sense of by the subject or person) preference or perception of complexity.

However, it could still be true that, in general, people with developed musical senses prefer more complex music in the tradition that they are used to. I think the solution of what tradition is ultimately the most complex would require better brain scanning equipment than we currently posses.

It seems that almost every day the Republican party is doing its best to reduce the chances that it will take control of the Senate next year, and is actively working against retaining control of the House.

They seem to be in the business of actively reducing their support among women and minorities nationwide, and I salute their efforts and encourage them to press on in their current direction.

Be honest, it is a complete distrust of government in general that drives the current political climate.  As for the Senate immigration bill, you would be a fool to believe anything in it would be enforced.  So, you can put together all kinds of legislation that sounds so fair, but in the end no one believes the corrupt political system will enforce anything.  All you will get is a continuation of dishonest, wasteful and abusive government. Sad.  Tom is living in a never never land.
We can only hope that the tide of illegal immigrants voting for Democrats will be turned back.  If not Democrats will always be elected by those illegals seeking citizenship and welfare.

With Republicans seemingly likely to control the House for the next decade or more, and reasonably likely to gain control of the Senate in 2014, it looks as though immigration reform, improved trade policies, and much more will remain in abeyance, even as much of the federal government (EPA, for example) will remain under attack.  By the 2014 election, we'll be accustomed to hamstrung presidents and a Congress of which the late North Carolina senator Jesse Helms would be proud.

This was known as the 300 SLR, with desdrumonic valve action, and roller bearing crank shaft bearings. The power takeoff was in the center of the engine to reduce crankshaft whip. The 300 SLR is also designated a W196 but is not open wheel.
